Our founders specifically did not grant the people the power to do anything by a vote except to elect people more qualified than themselves at making a decision. The vote of the majority almost always tends to oppress the minority, to force the minority to do what the majority wants, to destroy freedom and impose tyranny. There are two types of tyranny: there is tyranny of big government, but there is also the tyranny of the majority.
 
 To prevent this tyranny of the majority, our founders did not give the power to make these decisions directly to the people; they gave it to elected officials. These elected officials represent countless people. If you look back at debates between Federalists and Anti-Federalists, the Anti-Federalists were arguing that we have too few elected officials and that they can't possibly represent the people. But the Federalists argued back that we don't want a represtative who just holds the beliefs of a single majority group, we want a representative who appeals to a variety of groups and who will try to do what is best for everyone. Because it is more difficult for one faction to achieve a majority if an elected official represents a large number of people as opposed to a small, we can best prevent the tyranny of the majority by making a representative represent a large number of people.
 
 Well, I probably didn't explain that very well, but you can see The Federalist Papers #9, #10, and #51 for a better explanation, if you're interested. The point is, however, that the decision is not at all best left up to the majority; it is best left up to representatives who are informed on the subject and who will take the welfare of all people into consideration, not just the welfare of the majority. A simple vote is mob rule by people who are often uninformed and which results almost always in the destruction of freedom. Before America was founded, most political theorists believed that a democracy could never work because of this, that a democracy could never preserve freedom or equality.
